Award.AwardTitle: Radar Studies of Short-Term Variability in the Electrodynamics of the Low Latitude Ionosphere
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will address the nature of short-term (<1 month) variability of electrodynamic processes in the low-latitude ionosphere under both quiet and active geomagnetic conditions using statistical analysis of existing data from multiple sources. Specifically, the observations include incoherent scatter radar data from Jicamarca Radio Observatory in Peru, coherent scatter data from the JULIA radar system in Peru, and magnetic field data from the CHAMP satellite and ground-based magnetometers. The aim of the analysis is to quantify the effects on ionospheric variability from drivers in the lower atmosphere, such as planetary and tidal waves and sudden stratospheric warming events, as well as those associated with solar wind variability, which are communicated through the magnetosphere and high latitude ionosphere. The resulting quantifications will be used to develop empirical, altitude-dependent models of vertical and zonal winds and their response to climatological/weather variations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have used radar and satellite measurements to study the variability of electric fields and winds in the upper atmosphere, which affect the performance of low latitude communication and navigation systems. 

This project had two main focus. The first was the use of electric fields measurements in the ionosphere made at the very large radar at Jicamarca, near Lima Peru, and from the US Air Force C/NOFS satellite, and also magnetic field and upper atmospheric wind observations from the German CHAMP satellite to determine the characteristics of the low latitude ionospheric electric circuit.These parameters, which vary with local time, season, latitude, and longitude, are fundamentally important for forecasting space weather effects on space based systems including the GPS, and ground-based systems such as over-the-horizon radars. The second main focus was the use of these measurements for studying sudden extreme disruptions on the low latitude electrical circuit causing effects leading, for example, to GPS blackouts. The results of our experimental studies were used to determine and improve the performance of large numerical forecast models of the upper atmosphere. The results from these studies were published in a large number of scientifc publications and presented in numerous national and international meetings.

This project involved a large number of researchers from the U.S., Germany, Brazil, Peru, India, and China. It also had a strong graduate and undergraduate research component at Utah State University having provided support for 3 graduate and one undergraduate student.
